info.game_comments:
2006 Celebrity Jeopardy! game 4.
From Radio City Music Hall in New York City.

(1, 1).clue: This former Chicago Bull has a steakhouse in the station

(2, 1).clue: A scandalous, legendary Camelot couple: Lancevere

(3, 1).clue: A "chopper" can be a type of helicopter or a type of this vehicle

(4, 1).clue: It's been reigning over Broadway since 1997--long may it roar

(5, 1).clue: The Jacobson's organ in the roof of a snake's mouth is its organ of this sense, not taste

(6, 1).clue: An actor takes one during his curtain call

(1, 2).clue: This '60s first lady helped save Grand Central Station from destruction in the 1970s

(2, 2).clue: Bet their charity foundation gets free software: Billinda

(3, 2).clue: Appropriately, this Michigan city is known as "Motor City"

(4, 2).clue: Calling all swingers, you'll go ape over this musical

(5, 2).clue: The distinctive type of movement of the snake seen here gives it this name

(6, 2).clue: Throw away your oven & join Woody Harrelson in the movement for this type of food

(1, 3).clue: An entire alien civilization lives in a locker at Grand Central in the sequel to this Will Smith-Tommy Lee Jones film

(2, 3).clue: Sadly, marriage didn't work out for this New York showbiz couple:Daviza,with a D

(4, 3).clue: It's been a real tease since 2002

(5, 3).clue: Each year in India, up to 50,000 people are killed by kraits & these "hooded" snakes

(6, 3).clue: Muhammad Ali stung like a bee with this short, straight punch

(2, 4).clue: Stephen Colbert dubbed this acting duo Filliam H. Muffman

(4, 4).clue: "A Chorus Line" is "one singular sensation" again on Broadway with the music of this Tony-winning composer

(5, 4).clue: Crotalus horridus is the timber species of this "noisy" venomous snake

(6, 4).clue: A politician taking the low road is said to "sling" this

(2, 5).clue: Even today they get the royal treatment:Charilla

(4, 5).clue: It's the last name of the great Dame seen here, who, in 2004, was "Back With a Vengeance"

(6, 5).clue: Manly first name of British plotter Fawkes & "Sesame Street" game-show host Smiley

(1, 1).clue: Some thought she was on a spy mission when her plane disappeared over the Pacific in 1937

(2, 1).clue: In 1969 he placed a seismometer meant to detect moonquakes

(3, 1).clue: In 1970 this capital's Place de L'Etoile was renamed Place Charles de Gaulle

(4, 1).clue: His presidency saw the first federal budget surplus in 29 years but also the second impeachment of a president

(5, 1).clue: Alfred E. Neuman is the worry-free, gap-toothed cover boy of this humor magazine

(6, 1).clue: Discouraged by women's place in rock & roll, this Nova Scotian seen here started Lilith Fair in 1997

(1, 2).clue: In 1958 his castle & San Simeon estate became California State Historic Landmark No. 640

(2, 2).clue: This Revolutionary hero said, "If this be treason, make the most of it"--as well as the liberty or death bit

(3, 2).clue: This capital's Cathedral of the Archangel Michael is the burial site for many czars

(4, 2).clue: Two days after Fort Sumter fell, this president called for 75,000 men for the army & got more than he could equip

(5, 2).clue: In the names of magazines this word follows both Architectural & Reader's

(2, 3).clue: His film roles included Dumbledore in the "Harry Potter" series

(3, 3).clue: The Sphinx lies just a few miles southwest of this capital

(4, 3).clue: At a particularly rough time, John Dean said there was "a cancer growing on (his) presidency"

(5, 3).clue: In 1928 Time magazine chose its first "Man of the Year"; in 1985 this magazine began crowning "The Sexiest Man Alive"

(1, 4).clue: At his death in 1931, this Jersey boy had more than a thousand patents to his name

(2, 4).clue: After Buffalo Springfield broke up, this guy rejoined Stephen Stills & 2 others in 1969

(3, 4).clue: Built on the site of the Aztecs' capital, it later served as the capital of New Spain

(4, 4).clue: Televised hearings on the Iran-Contra affair revealed deep conflict among members of this Republican's administration

(5, 4).clue: Mick Jagger's band has been on the cover of this music magazine founded in 1967 more than anyone else--how fitting

(1, 5).clue: In 1721 he was proclaimed "Father of his Country", "Emperor of all Russia" & "the Great"

(2, 5).clue: This 7-foot center out of Georgetown starred for the Knicks in the '80s & '90s

(3, 5).clue: The old part of this European capital has 3 main squares: Dam, Leidseplein & Rembrandtsplein

(4, 5).clue: A stock-market crash during his presidency vacuumed up $40 billion in losses & 40% of the value of NYSE stocks

(5, 5).clue: This "national" magazine that takes readers all over the world has been around since 1888

(6, 5).clue: This alliterative femme was the first unsigned artist to have a No. 1 hit in the United States

(0, 0).clue: In the 1958 edition, this man penned the article on ventriloquism
